content: The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007, also known as the "Gas Price Relief Act," temporarily suspends motor fuel taxes. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends motor fuel taxes by setting the tax rates to zero during the suspension period. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends various motor fuel taxes by setting rates to zero, including taxes on diesel fuel, special motor fuels, compressed natural gas, additional taxes for the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund, certain alcohol fuels, gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, and the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends motor fuel taxes on diesel fuel, special motor fuels, compressed natural gas, alcohol fuels, gasoline, and kerosene, as well as taxes for the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund. Exceptions include taxes on fuel used in trains or motorboats and gasoline or kerosene used for aviation. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends motor fuel taxes on various fuels, excluding those used in trains, motorboats, and aviation. The suspension period lasts until the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline is below $3.00 per gallon for 6 consecutive months. Maintenance of trust fund deposits is also required. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends motor fuel taxes until the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline is below $3.00 per gallon for 6 consecutive months. Trust fund deposits must be maintained. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends motor fuel taxes until the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline is below $3.00 per gallon for 6 consecutive months, with trust fund deposits maintained. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF EXPENSING FOR CERTAIN REFINERIES. Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, regarding the election to expense certain refineries, is repealed. Technical amendments are made to various sections of the Code, removing references to 179C. The text amends various sections of the Internal Revenue Code by removing references to section 179C and transferring equivalent tax liabilities to the Highway Trust Fund. The text appropriates amounts equivalent to the net increase in tax liabilities under the Internal Revenue Code due to the repeal of section 179C, transferring these funds to the Highway Trust Fund based on estimates made by the Secretary of the Treasury. Adjustments will be made according to a schedule considering the timing of tax collection. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer funds to the Highway Trust Fund based on estimated tax liabilities, with adjustments made for prior estimates. These amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Before the enactment of this Act, if a tax was imposed on liquid held by a dealer for sale, the taxpayer can receive a credit or refund for the excess amount paid. No credit or refund will be allowed after a certain time for filing claims. The taxpayer can receive a credit or refund for excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the enactment of the Act. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the Act's enactment, and dealers must request refunds from taxpayers within 3 months. The Act allows dealers to request refunds from taxpayers for liquid held before enactment, with a 3-month deadline for submission. No credit or refund is allowed for liquid in retail stocks. No credit or refund allowed for liquid in retail stocks held by a dealer, except for fuel. Definitions of "dealer" and "held by a dealer" follow section 6412 of the Code. Similar rules to section 6412 apply. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed under the Internal Revenue Code if the taxable event occurred on that date. Liability for Tax: The person holding the liquid on the floor stocks tax date is responsible for paying the tax. Liability for Tax and Method of Payment: A person holding a liquid on the floor stocks tax date is liable for the tax imposed by subsection (a). The tax must be paid as prescribed by the Secretary, on or before the date that is 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. Definitions: A liquid is considered held by a person for the purposes of this section. The tax imposed by subsection (a) must be paid on or before the date that is 6 months after the floor stocks tax date. Definitions include what constitutes a liquid held by a person and what qualifies as a taxable liquid subject to the tax. The term "taxable liquid" refers to any liquid subject to a specific tax on the floor stocks tax date. The floor stocks tax date is defined as the day after the suspension period. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. The tax does not apply to taxable liquid held exclusively for exempt uses. The tax imposed by subsection (a) does not apply to taxable liquid held for exempt uses or in the tank of a motor vehicle or motorboat. No tax is imposed on any liquid held on the floor stocks tax date. No tax is imposed on liquid held on the floor stocks tax date if the amount does not exceed 2,000 gallons, and the required information is submitted to the Secretary. The tax exemption for fuel held by a person applies only if the required information is submitted to the Secretary. Fuel held by a person exempt from the tax is not considered. Controlled groups are treated as one person for tax purposes. For tax purposes, controlled groups are treated as one person, as defined in subsection (a) of section 1563 of the Code. The text discusses how the phrase "more than 50 percent" replaces "at least 80 percent" in certain tax regulations for groups of nonincorporated persons under common control. Under regulations set by the Secretary, similar principles to those in subparagraph (A) apply to a group of persons under common control where one or more is not a corporation. All relevant laws and penalties applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 of the Code also apply to floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a) to the same extent. SEC. 6. GASOLINE PRICE MONITORING. The Federal Trade Commission will monitor gasoline prices in the US, determining the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline monthly and reporting the results to Congress by the 15th day of each month. After 180 days, the Commission will report monitoring results to Congress and make it available to the public online. SEC. 7. COMMISSION ON GAS PRICE RELIEF. The Speaker of the House of Representatives will establish a Commission on Gas Price Relief within three months of this Act. The Commission will study the causes of high oil prices and submit a report to the House of Representatives within one year. The report will include revenue raisers to replenish the Treasury after suspending Federal excise taxes on motor fuels. The Commission on Gas Price Relief will consist of 9 Members, including the Chairmen of the Committees on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce. It aims to study high oil prices and propose revenue raisers to offset the loss from suspending Federal excise taxes on motor fuels. The Commission on Gas Price Relief will consist of 9 Members, including the Chairmen of the Committees on Ways and Means and Energy and Commerce, along with other members appointed by the Speaker and Chairmen. The Co-Chairs of the Commission will be the Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means and the Chairman of the Committee on Energy and Commerce.
